awd_abstract_narration:
The University of Mary Washington (UMW) is conducting The Jepson Scholars Program, providing four- year scholarships and integrated support to 20 academically talented students majoring in biology, chemistry, physics, and earth/environmental science.  The Jepson Scholars Program will recruit and serve a diverse low-income student population to develop skills needed for success in STEM graduate programs and careers. The program will therefore help meet the high demand for STEM workers throughout the region including Virginia and Washington, D.C.

This S-STEM project continues best practices of previous projects at UMW while implementing and assessing new activities including: (1) an early, 5-week summer research experience prior to freshman year with strong faculty mentoring; (2) an integrated first-year experience including a STEM-based first-year seminar, advising, and peer-assisted study sessions for gateway science classes; (3) continuing intensive research experiences with faculty mentorship; and (4) robust career preparation through an intensive series of workshops and cohort activities to educate students about STEM career and graduate school opportunities. The impact of these activities on enrollment and retention, graduation, and post-graduate placement rates are being investigated. Formative and summative project evaluation and assessment will employ mixed methods including collection of student data, surveys, interviews, and focus groups.  The intellectual merit of this project is enhanced by the results of this study, which will be used to support sustained programming at UMW and  inform similar institutions of effective practices to support low-income students and improve the numbers, quality, and diversity of STEM graduates.

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of the Jepson Scholars Program was to recruit and retain academically talented and low-income students to pursue and complete undergraduate degrees in biology, chemistry, earth and environmental sciences, and physics at the University of Mary Washington (UMW). We had four specific objectives: (1) to recruit and enroll 20 low-income and academically talented students to major in the natural sciences over the five-year grant period (two cohorts of 10 Jepson Scholars); (2) to increase research training and experience; (3) to increase retention and graduation; and (4) to improve placement of STEM graduates.

Toward this goal, we successfully recruited two cohorts of ten students with demonstrated financial need to study natural sciences. Students were awarded scholarships based on financial need (up to $10K, year; $604742 total scholarships over the life of award). All Scholars participated in a five-week Early Active Science Experience (EASE) program prior to their matriculation to UMW in 2018 and 2019. During EASE, pairs of Scholars joined pre-existing UMW Summer Science Institute (SSI) research teams consisting of one faculty + two rising sophomore-senior natural sciences majors; faculty served as mentors and the upper-level students served as peer mentors. Scholars were fully integrated into the research teams, and assisted in ongoing projects and developed and conducted their own projects. Scholars also participated in cohort-building and skills-building activities with other SSI participants. At the completion of the EASE program, Scholars presented their research at the SSI research symposium.

Upon matriculation at UMW, Scholars were enrolled as cohorts into science-themed first-year seminars taught by the faculty team, and in their appropriate introductory science courses. Scholars attended Peer Assisted Study Sessions (PASS) for their introductory chemistry courses. Scholars were encouraged to participate in undergraduate research beginning in their first year.

Six of the original 20 Scholars left the program during their first two years at UMW: two changed to non-STEM majors, three left UMW, and one made insufficient academic progress. Scholar positions were re-filled with high financial-need students majoring in the natural sciences.  

All Scholars gained substantive research experience throughout the program, either through SSI, URES, or both. Eighteen Scholars conducted research during the academic year; 15 of the 18 conducted research for three or more semesters. Sixteen Scholars participated in the 10-week UMW SSI after their 2nd or 3rd year; one Scholar participated in an NSF-REU. Eleven Scholars presented their research at scientific conferences (3 state, 2 regional, and 10 national/ international meetings).

Of the original 20 Scholars, 14 graduated with a BS: one in 3.5 years, 12 in 4 years, and one in 4.5 years. The 70% rate of retention of Jepson Scholars from first year to graduation in a STEM discipline exceeds the first-to-second year retention in STEM fields at UMW. Of the six replacement Scholars, five graduated within 4 years of matriculation; one moved out-of-state and plans to complete a STEM degree at another institution.

Of the 19 graduating Scholars, 17 have reported placement or post-graduate plans in STEM fields. Seven Scholars are currently enrolled in post-graduate programs in the natural sciences (5), medicine (1), and biotechnology patent law (1), and one is applying to post-graduate programs. Ten Scholars are employed in positions requiring STEM degrees and training.

The PI and co-PIs presented aspects of the project at seven national/ international scientific and science pedagogy conferences.


Last Modified: 07/11/2024
Modified by: Dianne M Baker
